the number of copies required by this chapter and in accordance with the
procedures for submission set forth in this chapter, along with written notice
that the document is in the final form intended by the subdivider to be
officially filed with or submitted to the city.  Further, the providing of a
copy of a plat, replat, amended plat, pre-submission proposal, infrastructure
permit application or other document required by this chapter to the City
Planner by the pre-submission review deadline (or by another deadline preceding
the pre-submission deadline) for purposes of pre-submission review by city
staff shall not be construed as submission of said document to the city or
filing of said document with the city; provided, however, that for purposes of
any other relevant deadlines, any document so provided shall be considered to
be submitted to and/or filed with the city on the latter of (1) the first day
of the submission period if the document otherwise meets the requirements of
this section or (2) the day on which the subdivider submits said document in
the final form intended by the subdivider to be officially filed with or
submitted to the city and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)    Pre-submission proposal not plat, replat or amended plat.  For purposes
of this chapter and of any other law, the term “plat” does not include the pre-
submission proposal required by this chapter; the term “replat” does not
include the pre-submission proposal required by this chapter; and the term
“plat amendment” or “amended plat” does not include the pre-submission proposal
required by this chapter. The submission or provision of a pre-submission
proposal does not constitute the submission of or filing of a plat, replat, or
amended plat.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-28.   Withdrawal of plat.
(a)    Procedure for withdrawal.  At any time before the approval of a plat by
the Commission, the person or persons applying for approval of the plat may
withdraw the plat and/or any associated permits and applications by filing with
the City Planner a written statement requesting to withdraw the plat.  The
statement shall be in a form acceptable to the City Attorney and shall be
signed by the same persons who signed the application for the plat (or for any
associated permits, such as the infrastructure permit) or by those persons’
duly authorized representatives.  The City Attorney may require proof that a
person signing on another’s behalf is duly authorized to do so.  A withdrawal
shall be effective on the effective date specified in the withdrawal.  If an
effective date is not expressly stated in a withdrawal, the withdrawal shall be
effective immediately upon its receipt by the City Planner in a form that meets
the requirements of this section.
(b)    Effect of withdrawal. If a plat or the permits and applications
associated with a plat are withdrawn in accordance with this section, the plat
and all associated permits and applications shall be considered null and void
immediately upon the effective date of withdrawal.  Such a plat shall no longer
be considered to be filed and shall not be considered approved by virtue of the
fact that it is not disapproved within 30 days after it was originally filed. 
Any succeeding plat request and any related applications and permits shall be
considered a new plat request and shall be subject to all the requirements of
law in effect at the time of the succeeding plat request, application, or
permit.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-29.   Signing of approved plats, amended plats and replats.
Upon the approval of a plat, amended plat or replat in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter by the City Planner and only after the posting of
any associated security required by this chapter, the plat shall be signed by
the City Planner. Upon the approval of a plat, amended plat or replat in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter by the Commission and only after
the posting of any associated security required by this chapter, the plat shall
be signed by either (1) the Chair of the Commission with the secretary of the
Commission attesting to the Chair's signature or (2) a majority of the members
of the Commission.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 11, 9-12-02; Ord No. 3661, § 2
9-10-09)
Sec. 92-30.    Permits, certificates and licenses.
(a)   Construction permits, general rule.  Except as expressly authorized by
this section, the city shall not issue any permit, certificate or license for
the construction or building of any structure or portion of a structure within
a subdivision unless all of the following are true:
   (1)   any plat required by law for the subdivision has been approved; and
   (2)   all regulated improvements within the subdivision have been completed
in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and the City Engineer has
confirmed said completion in writing. 
(b)   Certificates of occupancy, general rule.  Except as expressly authorized
by this section, the city shall not issue any approval, permit, certificate or
license authorizing the occupancy of any structure or portion of a structure
within a subdivision unless all of the following are true:
   (1)   any plat required by law for the subdivision has been approved; and
   (2)   all regulated improvements within the subdivision have been completed
in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and the City Engineer has
confirmed such completion in writing. 
(c)   Permit for construction of foundation.  Any other provisions of this
section notwithstanding, after acceptance by the City Engineer of the plans and
specifications required by Section 92-24 of this chapter, the city may issue
any permit, certificate or license necessary for the construction of (but not
authorizing the occupancy of) the foundation of a building or structure;
provided, however, that such permit, certificate or license may authorize the
construction of only the foundation of the building and that such permit,
certificate or license must be issued in accordance with the requirements of
any applicable city codes and ordinances.
(d)   Construction permits where fire protection available.  Any other
provisions of this section notwithstanding, the city may issue any permit,
certificate or license for the construction or building of (but not authorizing
the occupancy of) any structure or portion of a structure within a subdivision
if all of the following are true:
   (1)   there is access to the proposed structure for which the permit is
requested;
   (2)   the required access has a surface and width that complies the
applicable requirements of the fire code;
   (3)   the distance between the required access and the structure complies
with the applicable requirements of the fire code;
   (4)   a water supply meeting all applicable requirements of the fire code is
available for the suppression of fire at said structure as required by the fire
code;
   (5)   such permit, certificate or license is issued in accordance with the
requirements of any applicable city codes and ordinances; and.
   (6)   the City Engineer has received and found acceptable the plans and
specifications required by Section 92-24 of this chapter.
(e)   Temporary improvements.  This section shall not be construed to prohibit
the issuance of any license, permit or certificate necessary for the
construction or occupancy of any temporary improvement; provided that any such
temporary improvement is constructed in accordance with all applicable
requirements of this chapter and any required security is posted in accordance
with the requirements of this chapter. 
(f)   Regulated improvements.  This section shall not be construed to prohibit
the issuance of any license, permit or certificate necessary for the
construction of any regulated improvement.
(g)   Illegal transfers.  This section shall not be construed to and does not
authorize the issuance of any approval, permit, certificate or license
authorizing the construction, building or occupancy of any structure or portion
of a structure on land transferred or conveyed in violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3241, § 6, 8-28-03)
Secs. 92-31 - 92-45.  Reserved.
Article III.
Track 1:  Post-Construction Plat Submission
Sec. 92-46.   Application of this article.
Except to the extent expressly provided otherwise by this chapter, this article
applies only to a subdivision for which the subdivider has elected the Track 1
approval procedure under Section 92-19 of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-47.   Infrastructure permit.
(a)   Pre-submission proposal required; variance request.  If a subdivider
chooses the Track 1 approval procedure, the subdivider shall work with the City
Planner and the City Engineer to prepare a version of the pre-submission
proposal that complies with the requirements of this chapter, including without
limitation the requirements of Section 92-16.  Alternatively, the subdivider
may prepare a version of the pre-submission proposal that does not fully comply
with the provisions of this chapter and concurrently submit a request for a
variance for those aspects of the proposed subdivision that do not comply with
the provisions of this chapter.  Such a variance request must conform to the
requirements of Section 92-26 of this chapter.
(b)   Application for infrastructure permit.  Once the subdivider has the pre-
submission proposal in final form, the subdivider shall complete an application
for an infrastructure permit.  The application shall be in a form approved by
the City Planner and shall include copies of the pre-submission proposal.  The
number of copies of said proposal that must be provided shall be as determined
by the City Planner, not to exceed eight physical copies and one electronic
copy, each copy in the form required by the City Planner.  The application and
accompanying copies of the pre-submission proposal must be received by the City
Planner by or before the pre-submission review deadline.  If the infrastructure
permit application or any of the required materials are not received by or
before the pre-submission review deadline, the permit application may be
disapproved by the Commission.
(c)   Approval authority for infrastructure permit.  The City Planner and City
Engineer jointly may approve an infrastructure permit application and issue an
infrastructure permit if the pre-submission application does not require a
variance, but may not disapprove an infrastructure permit application.  If an
infrastructure permit application requires a variance, then the permit
application (and variance, if one is requested) shall be scheduled for
consideration at the next available Commission meeting.  Additionally, the City
Planner, the City Engineer or the subdivider may, for any reason, elect to
present an infrastructure permit application to the Commission for approval/
disapproval/conditional approval; provided, however, that the infrastructure
permit application must be placed on the Commission agenda before the posting
deadline.  If the subdivider does not agree to conditions of approval imposed
by the City Planner or the City Engineer, the subdivider shall submit written
notice of such to the City Planner before the posting deadline, whereupon the
infrastructure permit application will be scheduled for consideration at the
next available Commission meeting.  Action will be taken on the infrastructure
permit application as set forth in Section 92-48 of this chapter.
(d)   Sight-distance study/traffic impact analysis.  If the City Engineer
requires a sight-distance study and/or traffic impact analysis under the
authority of Section 92-18 of this chapter and the pre-submission proposal is
scheduled to be presented to the Commission, then the requested study and/or
analysis must be submitted to the City Engineer at least five calendar days
prior to the date on which the Commission is scheduled to review the pre-
submission proposal.  If such a study and/or analysis is required and the pre-
submission proposal is not scheduled to be presented to the Commission, then
the City Engineer shall review the study and/or analysis and specify any
stricter standards required by the City Engineer (under the authority of
Section 92-98 of this chapter) within five calendar days after the City
Engineer receives the requested study and/or analysis.  If the City Engineer
has requested such a study and/or analysis, no infrastructure permit shall be
issued until said study and/or analysis has been submitted to the City Engineer
in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, §§ 12, 13, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-48.   Commission consideration of infrastructure permit.
On receipt of the infrastructure permit application and other information
required by this chapter, the Commission shall take one of the following
actions within 30 days from the date on which the application was officially
submitted to the city in accordance with Section 92-27 of this chapter:
(a)   approval of the requested infrastructure permit;
(b)   disapproval of the requested infrastructure permit; or
(c)   conditional approval of the requested infrastructure permit.
   Conditional approval of an infrastructure permit shall be disapproval of the
infrastructure permit until compliance with the prescribed conditions, but
shall be deemed to be approval of such infrastructure permit upon compliance
with such conditions.  All objections made to the infrastructure permit, and
any conditions imposed on the infrastructure permit, shall be furnished by the
City Planner to the subdivider in writing.  If an infrastructure permit is
neither disapproved nor conditionally approved by the Commission within 30 days
from the date on which the application was officially submitted to the city in
accordance with Section 92-27 of this chapter, it shall be deemed to have been
issued.  Denial of an infrastructure permit by the Commission shall be final
and may not be appealed to the City Council.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 14, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-49.   Plans and specifications required.
After the approval of an infrastructure permit and before beginning the
construction of any of the regulated improvements, the subdivider shall submit
to the City Engineer plans and specifications, as per Section 92-24 of this
chapter, for the section or sections of the tract intended for immediate
development.  The Commission shall disapprove any plat for which the subdivider
has not submitted plans and specifications to the City Engineer as required by
Section 92-24 of this chapter.  The Commission shall disapprove any plat for
which the plans and specifications have not been accepted by the City Engineer
in accordance with Section 92-24; provided, however, that the Commission may
grant a variance upon proper application by the subdivider in accordance with
Section 92-26.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 15, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-50.   Amendment of infrastructure permit.
(a)    Application for infrastructure permit amendment. After the issuance of
an infrastructure permit, the subdivider may request an amendment to said
permit.  The amendment request shall be in a form approved by the City Planner
and shall include such information as reasonably required by the City Planner
and City Engineer.  The number of copies of said amendment request that must be
provided shall be as determined by the City Planner, not to exceed eight
physical copies and one electronic copy, each copy in the form required by the
City Planner.  The amendment request and any accompanying materials required by
the City Planner or City Engineer must be received by the City Planner by or
before the pre-submission review deadline.  If the amendment request or any of
the required materials are not received by or before the pre-submission review
deadline, the permit application may be disapproved by the Commission.
(b)   Approval authority for infrastructure permit amendment.  The City Planner
and City Engineer jointly may, in their discretion, approve an amendment
request so long as such amendment does not require a variance, but may not
disapprove an amendment request.  If an amendment requires a variance, then the
amendment (and variance, if one is requested) shall be scheduled for
consideration at the next available Commission meeting.  Additionally, the City
Planner, the City Engineer or the subdivider may, for any reason, elect to
present an amendment request to the Commission for approval/disapproval/
conditional approval; provided, however, that the amendment request must be
placed on the Commission agenda before the posting deadline.  If the subdivider
does not agree to conditions of approval imposed by the City Planner or City
Engineer, the subdivider shall submit written notice of such to the City
Planner before the posting deadline, whereupon the amendment request will be
scheduled for consideration at the next available Commission meeting.  Action
will be taken on the amendment request in the same manner as for an
infrastructure permit application, as set forth in Section 92-48 of this
chapter.  However, neither the application for nor the approval of any
amendment to an infrastructure permit shall extend or otherwise alter any of
the deadlines set forth in this chapter, including without limitation the
submission period, the pre-submission review deadline and any other deadlines
for complying with any other requirements of this chapter. 
(c)   Withdrawal of application for infrastructure permit amendment.  At any
time before the approval of an amendment request, the person or persons
requesting the amendment may withdraw the amendment request by filing with the
City Planner a written statement requesting to withdraw the amendment request. 
The statement shall be in a form acceptable to the City Attorney.  A withdrawal
shall be effective on the effective date specified in the withdrawal.  If an
effective date is not expressly stated in a withdrawal, the withdrawal shall be
effective immediately upon its receipt by the City Planner in a form that meets
the requirements of this section.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 16, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-51.   Expiration of infrastructure permit; extension.
If the requirements for approval of the permit have not been met and no plat
has been submitted at the end of one year from the date that the infrastructure
permit was issued, the infrastructure permit shall become null and void.  The
subdivider may apply to the City Planner in writing for a one-time, 12-month
administrative extension prior to the expiration of one year from the date that
the infrastructure permit was issued, citing reasonable cause for an extension
and demonstrating that the subdivider is actively pursuing the development of
construction plans or a plat.  For example, the City Planner may grant such an
extension if a corresponding plat is active, if the subdivision is under
construction or if construction plans are in the possession of the city and
under review by city staff at the time of the request for an extension.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 17, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-52.   Plat submission.
After completion of all regulated improvements within the subdivision in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, a subdivider shall prepare and
submit to the Commission a plat that complies with the requirements of Section
92-20 and the other applicable provisions of this chapter.  If the subdivider
has elected to develop the subdivision shown on the pre-submission proposal in
phases or sections, the plat shall include only those sections or phases of the
subdivision which meet the following requirements: (1) the plans and
specifications for said sections or phases have been accepted by the City
Engineer, and (2) the subdivider has completed all regulated improvements
included in said plans and specifications in accordance with said plans and
specifications and with the provisions of this chapter.
The subdivider shall submit to the Commission the plat and an accompanying
application in a form approved by the City Planner. The number of copies of the
plat that must be submitted shall be as determined by the City Planner, not to
exceed eight physical copies and one electronic copy, each copy in the form
required by the City Planner.  The application and accompanying copies of the
plat must be submitted to the City Planner during the submission period.  If
the application, plat or any of the required materials are not submitted during
the submission period, the plat may be disapproved by the Commission.  No lots
within a subdivision may be sold until a plat is approved by the Commission.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 18, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-53.   Commission consideration of plat.
The Commission shall take one of the following actions within 30 days from the
date on which the plat was officially submitted to the city in accordance with
Section 92-27 of this chapter:
(a)   approval of the plat;
(b)   disapproval of the plat; or
(c)   conditional approval of the plat.
   Conditional approval of a plat shall be disapproval of the plat until
compliance with the prescribed conditions, but shall be deemed to be approval
of such plat upon compliance with such conditions.  All objections made to the
plat, and any conditions imposed on the plat, shall be furnished by the City
Planner to the subdivider in writing. If a plat is neither disapproved nor
conditionally approved by the Commission within 30 days from the date on which
the plat application was officially submitted to the city in accordance with
Section 92-27 of this chapter, it shall be deemed to have been approved by the
Commission.  Disapproval of a plat by the Commission shall be final and may not
be appealed to the City Council.
   The Commission shall disapprove the plat if the subdivider has failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this chapter and no variance is granted
for the noncompliance.  For purposes of this section, the phrase “failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this chapter” includes any one or more
of the following: (1) the failure to provide a pre-submission proposal that
complies with the applicable requirements of this chapter, (2) the failure to
construct any regulated improvements in accordance with the applicable
requirements of this chapter, (3) the failure to comply with any of the
applicable deadlines (including without limitation the submission period and
the pre-submission review deadline) imposed by this chapter or imposed in
accordance with the provisions hereof, (4) the failure to provide a plat that
complies with the applicable requirements of this chapter, (5) the failure to
post or have posted the required maintenance bonds, and (6) any failure to
comply with any other applicable requirement or provision of this chapter. 
Upon the approval of the plat by the Commission, the plat may be filed with the
County Clerk.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 19, 9-12-02)
Secs. 92-54 - 92-65.  Reserved.
Article IV.
Track 2: Pre-Construction Plat Submission
Sec. 92-66.   Application of this article.
Except to the extent expressly provided otherwise by this chapter, this article
applies only to a subdivision for which the subdivider has elected the Track 2
approval procedure under Section 92-19 of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-67.   Pre-submission proposal required.
(a)   Pre-submission proposal required; variance request.  If a subdivider
chooses the Track 2 approval procedure, the subdivider shall work with the City
Planner and the City Engineer to prepare a version of the pre-submission
proposal that complies with the requirements of this chapter, including without
limitation the requirements of Section 92-16.  Alternatively, the subdivider
may prepare a version of the pre-submission proposal that does not fully comply
with the provisions of this chapter and concurrently submit a request for a
variance for those aspects of the proposed subdivision that do not comply with
the provisions of this chapter.  Such a variance request must conform to the
requirements of Section 92-26 of this chapter. The number of copies of the pre-
submission proposal that must be provided shall be as determined by the City
Planner, not to exceed eight physical copies and one electronic copy, each copy
in the form required by the City Planner.  The pre-submission proposal shall be
provided to the City Planner by the pre-submission review deadline.
(b)   Sight-distance study/traffic impact analysis.  If the City Engineer
requires a sight-distance study and/or traffic impact analysis under the
authority of Section 92-18 of this chapter, then the requested study and/or
analysis must be submitted to the City Engineer at least 5 calendar days prior
to the date on which the Commission is scheduled to review the plat.  If the
City Engineer has requested such a study and/or analysis, no plat shall be
issued until said study and/or analysis has been submitted to the City Engineer
in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 20, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-68.   Plat submission.
Once the subdivider has the pre-submission proposal in final form, the
subdivider shall prepare and submit to the Commission a plat that complies with
the requirements of Section 92-20 and any other applicable provisions in this
chapter.  If the subdivider intends to develop the subdivision shown on the
pre-submission proposal in phases or sections, the plat shall include only
those sections or phases of the subdivision that the subdivider intends for
immediate development.
The subdivider shall submit to the Commission the plat and any supporting
documentation required by the City Planner (such as the associated application
and any variance requested) in a from approved by the City Planner.  The number
of copies of the plat that must be submitted shall be as determined by the City
Planner, not to exceed eight physical copies and one electronic copy, each copy
in the form required by the City Planner.  The application and accompanying
copies of the plat must be submitted to the City Planner during the submission
period.  If the application, plat or any of the required materials are not
submitted during the submission period, the plat may be disapproved by the
Commission.  No lots within a subdivision may be sold until a plat is approved
by the Commission.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 21, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-69.   Commission consideration of plat.
The Commission shall take one of the following actions within 30 days from the
date on which the plat was officially submitted to the city in accordance with
Section 92-27 of this chapter:
(a)   approval of the plat;
(b)   disapproval of the plat; or
(c)   conditional approval of the plat.
   Conditional approval of a plat shall be disapproval of the plat until
compliance with the prescribed conditions, but shall be deemed to be approval
of such plat upon compliance with such conditions.  All objections made to the
plat, and any conditions imposed on the plat, shall be furnished by the City
Planner to the subdivider in writing.  If a plat is neither disapproved nor
conditionally approved by the Commission within 30 days from the date on which
the plat application was officially submitted to the city in accordance with
Section 92-27 of this chapter, it shall be deemed to have been approved by the
Commission.  Disapproval of a plat by the Commission shall be final and may not
be appealed to the City Council.
   The Commission shall disapprove the plat if the subdivider has failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this chapter and no variance is granted
for the noncompliance.  For purposes of this section, the phrase “failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this chapter” includes any one or more
of the following: (1) the failure to provide a pre-submission proposal that
complies with the applicable requirements of this chapter, (2) the failure to
comply with any of the applicable deadlines (including without limitation the
submission period and the pre-submission review deadline) imposed by this
chapter or imposed in accordance with the provisions hereof, (3) the failure to
provide a plat that complies with the applicable requirements of this chapter
and (4) any failure to comply with any other applicable requirement or
provision of this chapter. After approval of the plat by the Commission and the
posting of any and all security required by Section 92-72 or by any other
provision of this chapter, the plat may be filed with the County Clerk.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 22, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-70.   Plans and specifications required.
After the approval of a plat by the Commission and before beginning the
construction of any of the regulated improvements, the subdivider shall submit
to the City Engineer plans and specifications, as per Section 92-24 of this
chapter, for the section or sections of the tract intended for immediate
development. 
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-71.   Completion of improvements required; expiration of plat;
extension.
No later than one year following the date on which a plat is approved by the
Commission the subdivider shall complete the regulated improvements in
accordance with the plans and specifications accepted by the City Engineer
under Section 92-24 of this chapter.  If the regulated improvements have not
been completed one year from the date that the plat was approved, the city may
take any of the actions described in Section 92-73 and/or in Article VIII of
this chapter.  The subdivider may apply to the City Planner in writing for a
one-time, 12-month administrative extension prior to the expiration of one year
from the date that the plat was approved, citing reasonable cause for an
extension and demonstrating that the subdivider is actively pursuing the
development of construction plans or is constructing the regulated
improvements.  For example, the City Planner may grant such an extension if the
subdivision is under construction or if construction plans are in the
possession of the city and under review by city staff at the time of the
request for an extension.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-72.   Security for improvements.
(a)   Types of security required.  Before filing a plat or selling any lots in
a plat, the subdivider shall provide sufficient security to cover the
completion of the regulated improvements in accordance with the standards set
forth in this chapter.  The security shall be in the form of a cash escrow,
letter of credit or other security acceptable to the City Attorney.  Security
shall be in an amount equal to 100% of the estimated cost of completion of the
regulated improvements.  The issuer of any letter of credit or other security
shall be subject to approval of the City Attorney and all letters of credit and
other security shall be in a form acceptable to the City Attorney.
(b)   Requirements for letter of credit.  If the subdivider elects to post a
letter of credit as security for the completion of the regulated improvements,
the letter of credit shall:
   (1)   be irrevocable;
   (2)   be for a term sufficient to cover the completion, maintenance and
warranty periods but in no event less than two years; and
   (3)   require only that the city present the issuer with a sight draft and a
certificate signed by an authorized representative of the city certifying to
the city's right to draw funds under the letter of credit.
(c)   Reduction/release of security.  As portions of the regulated improvements
are completed in accordance with the plans and specifications accepted by the
City Engineer and in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, the
subdivider may make application to the City Engineer to reduce the amount of
the original letter of credit.  If the City Engineer is satisfied that such
portion of the regulated improvements has been completed in accordance with
city standards, the City Engineer may (but is not required to) cause the amount
of the letter of credit to be reduced by such amount deemed appropriate, so
that the remaining amount of the letter of credit adequately insures the
completion of the remaining regulated improvements.
   Upon the issuance by the City Engineer of the letter required by Section 92-
25 of this chapter and the receipt by the City Engineer of any signed
compliance letter required under said section, the city shall authorize a
reduction in the security to twenty (20) percent of the original amount of the
security if the subdivider is not in violation of this chapter.  The remaining
security, if any, shall serve as  security for the maintenance of the regulated
improvements and the warrant that the regulated improvements are free from
defect for one year thereafter.  If the subdivider’s contractors or others
provide the required security for maintenance and warranty, the city shall 
release the entire amount of the subdivider security.
(d)   Temporary improvements.  The subdivider shall build and pay for all costs
of temporary improvements required by the City Engineer and shall maintain
those temporary improvements for the period specified by the Commission.  Prior
to construction of any temporary facility or temporary improvement, the
subdivider shall file with the city an escrow or, where authorized, a letter of
credit or other security authorized by the City Attorney, in an appropriate
amount for temporary facilities, which security shall ensure that the temporary
facilities will be properly constructed, maintained, and removed. 
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 23, 9-12-02; Ord. No. 3441, § 4,
4-13-06)
Sec. 92-73.   Enforcement of security requirements; failure of improvements to
comply.
The failure to post the security required by Section 92-72 of this chapter
(including without limitation the failure to post said security before the
filing of the associated plat and/or the sale of any lots in said plat) is a
violation of this chapter.  No permit, license or certificate authorizing the
construction, building or occupancy of any structure may be issued within a
subdivision for which the security required by this chapter has not been
posted.  In those cases where security has been posted and the regulated
improvements have not been installed or have not been installed in a manner
that complies with the provisions of this chapter and the plans and
specifications accepted by the City Engineer, the city may:
(a)   require that all the regulated improvements be installed regardless of
the extent of completion of the development at the time;
(b)   obtain funds under the security and complete the regulated improvements
itself or through a third party;
(c)   assign its right to receive funds under the security to any third party,
including a subsequent subdivider of the subdivision or addition for which
regulated improvements were not constructed in compliance with this chapter, in
whole or in part, in exchange for that subsequent subdivider’s promise to
complete and/or repair the regulated improvements on the tract;
(d)   place a moratorium on the issuance of any further construction permits
and/or any other permits, licenses or certificates required in the subdivision
until the satisfactory completion of the regulated improvements; and/or
(e)   exercise any other rights available under the law.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 24, 9-12-02)
Secs. 92-74 - 92-85.  Reserved.
Article V.
Track 3: Staff Approval of Minor Plat
Sec. 92-86.   Track 3: Staff approval of minor plat.
(a)   Definition of minor plat.  A subdivision determined to meet each of the
following requirements may be classified as "minor" and approved in accordance
with the procedures set forth in this article:
   (1)   proposed lots shall front onto an existing street; and
   (2)   four or fewer lots are proposed; and
   (3)   proposed plat does not require either the construction or extension of
streets or the extension of municipal facilities; and
   (4)   proposed subdivision is not a replat.
(b)   Pre-submission proposal, plat required for minor plat.  The subdivider of
a minor plat shall cause a pre-submission proposal to be prepared as set forth
in Section 92-16 of this chapter. Upon approval of the pre-submission proposal
for a minor plat by the City Planner, the subdivider shall prepare a plat, per
Section 92-20 of this chapter, and submit said plat to the City Planner for
approval.  The minor plat shall be submitted during the submission period.
(c)   Approval authority for minor plat. The City Planner may approve a minor
plat so long as such minor plat does not require a variance, but may not
disapprove a minor plat. If a minor plat is not approved by the City Planner
before the posting deadline or if a minor plat requires a variance, the minor
plat (and variance, if one is requested) shall be scheduled for consideration
at the next available Commission meeting.  Additionally, the City Planner or
the subdivider may, for any reason, elect to present a minor plat to the
Commission for approval/disapproval/conditional approval; provided, however,
that the minor plat must be placed on the Commission agenda before the posting
deadline.  If the subdivider does not agree to conditions of approval imposed
by the City Planner, the subdivider shall submit written notice of such to the
City Planner before the posting deadline, whereupon the minor plat will be
scheduled for consideration at the next available Commission meeting.  Action
will be taken on the former minor plat as set forth in Section 92-69 of this
chapter. If the plat does not meet the requirements necessary to be considered
as a minor plat, the subdivider may resubmit the plat in accordance with the
procedures provided under Article III of this chapter (Track 1) or under
Article IV of this chapter (Track 2), whichever the subdivider shall elect.
(d)   Signing and filing of minor plat.  After the minor plat is approved by
the City Planner or by the Commission, it shall be signed as required by
Section 92-29 and filed with the County Clerk.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Secs. 92-87 - 92-95.  Reserved.
Article VI.
Required Improvements and Design Standards
Sec. 92-96.   Required improvements.
(a)   Improvements required.  The subdivider shall construct each and every
improvement required by this chapter, including without limitation, each and
every improvement required by the subdivision design standards.
(b)   Conformity with regulations required.  The regulated improvements
required by this chapter shall be installed within all of the area of any
subdivision for which the City Engineer has accepted the plans and
specifications in accordance with Section 92-24 of this chapter.  All regulated
improvements shall be designed and constructed in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter.  None of the regulated improvements and no
construction of any nature on the subdivided tract shall commence until the
City Engineer has accepted the plans and specifications required by Section 92-
24 of this chapter.
(c)   Required information and markers.  It shall be the responsibility of the
subdivider to provide construction staking, cut sheets, shop drawings and
construction change orders, as-built plans, construction costs (unit price
breakdown) for all public improvements, and other information required to
complete the construction. Within 30 days after the issuance by the City
Engineer of the letter required by Section 92-25 of this chapter, certified as-
built plans shall be submitted to the city on paper and in a digital format
acceptable to the City Engineer.  If the complete and correct as-built drawings
are not submitted within the 30 days, no additional permit, certificate or
license authorizing the occupancy, construction or building of any structure or
portion of a structure within the subdivision shall be issued until such
drawings are submitted to the City Engineer.
   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to emplace permanent survey
reference monuments and lot and block corner markers.  It shall also be the
responsibility of the subdivider to replace any such monuments and corner
markers that are destroyed or removed before the completion of all regulated
improvements in the subdivision and the city’s acceptance of all public
improvements in the subdivision.  Such corners and monuments shall be of 3/4-
inch iron pipe or 5/8-inch iron rod and shall meet the following standards:
   (1)   lot corners shall be located with a half-inch iron rod 24 inches long
with the top flush with the ground.
   (2)   block corners shall be located with a 5/8-inch iron rod 36 inches long
top set flush with the ground and shall include the beginning and end of all
curves within each block.
   (3)   reference points shall be 24-30 inches long placed one foot below the
surface of the finished ground elevation at suitable locations throughout the
subdivision.  At least two reference points shall be tied to the City of
Longview, Texas, 2002 Mapping and Monumentation Project Horizontal and Vertical
Control Network.  There shall be at least as many reference points as there are
blocks in the subdivision but not less than two, and the distance between the
successive monuments along any street or reference line shall not be greater
than 1,000 feet.  Reference points shall be other than and in addition to
markers for block or lot corners.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-97.   Improvement standards.
The following minimum standards for regulated improvements shall apply and
shall be agreed to and complied with in each subdivision:
(a)   Pavement.  All streets shall be paved in accordance with the plans and
specifications accepted by the City Engineer of the City of Longview, Texas.
Width of paving for the various types of streets, shall be determined by the
City Engineer according to his determination of the street classification
appropriate to each street and shall not be less than the following:
   Street Type                    Pavement Section Width
   Principal arterial         66'
   Minor arterial            53'
   Collector            37'
   Local                29'
   Private street            Per fire code
(b)   Curb and gutters, water lines, sanitary sewer and drainage structures. 
Combined curb and gutters on each side of all public streets in the
subdivision, waterlines providing access to water to each lot in the
subdivision, sanitary sewer system lines providing access to sanitary sewer to
each lot in the subdivision, and drainage pipes, channels, inlets, junction
boxes and other appurtenances necessary to convey and transport surface
drainage, shall be constructed or installed in accordance with the plans and
specifications accepted by the City Engineer.  Long-side service lines shall be
installed by the subdivider for each lot on the opposite side of the street
from the water or wastewater mains.  Short-side service lines shall be
installed by the subdivider during the initial construction of the subdivision
in those instances where the flowline of the sewer main is six feet or more
below the finished grade of the curb or edge of pavement elevation. Outside of
the corporate limits of the city, the subdivider may install water wells in
place of the required waterlines where an approved public water supply is not
reasonably accessible or procurable.  Each lot in the subdivision must still
have access to water.  Outside of the corporate limits of the city, the
subdivider may install on-site sewage facilities in place of the required
sanitary sewer system lines where a public sanitary sewer system is not
reasonably accessible or procurable. Each lot in the subdivision must still
have access to a means of disposing of sewage that complies with all applicable
law.  Any water well or on-site sewage facility so installed must comply with
the plans and specifications accepted by the City Engineer.
(c)   On-site sewage facilities.  For any subdivision where an on-site sewage
facility is installed, any and all on-site sewage facilities (commonly called
“septic tanks” or “septic systems”) must meet all applicable requirements of
Texas law, including without limitation any applicable requirements of the
Texas Commission on Environmental Quality or its successor agency or agencies. 
The subdivider must show proof that the county in which said subdivision is
located has found that any necessary on-site sewage facilities will not violate
the state regulations that the county is required to enforce.  The City
Engineer may require such inspections and proof of compliance with this
subsection as the City Engineer deems appropriate.
(d)   On-site water supply systems.  For any subdivision where water wells are
installed, any water wells or other water supply systems must meet all
applicable requirements of Texas law, including without limitation any
applicable requirements of the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality or its
successor agency or agencies.
(e)   Fire hydrants.  Fire hydrants shall be installed in the proposed
subdivision in a manner that complies with the requirements of the fire code.
(f)   Street lights.  Street lights shall be installed by the subdivider at the
intervals recommended by the city’s franchised electric utility supplier or at
other intervals as determined by the City Engineer.
(g)   Applicable design standards.  Each and every regulated improvement and
public improvement shall meet the applicable design standards of the
subdivision design standards.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3241, § 7, 8-28-03; Ord. No. 3525, § 39,
6-14-07)
Sec. 92-98.  Design standards for streets.
(a)   Conformity to general plan and other considerations.  The arrangement,
character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to
the general plan for the city and shall be considered in their relation to
existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public
convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses
of the land to be served by such streets.  All streets shall be installed in
the proposed subdivision in a manner that complies with the requirements of the
fire code, and public streets shall comply with the Design Guidelines for
Subdivision Street Improvements in Longview, Texas.
(b)   Arrangement of streets not in general plan.  Where such is not shown in
the general plan for the city, the arrangement of streets in a subdivision
shall either:
   (1)   provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing
principal streets in surrounding area; or
   (2)   conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved or adopted by the
Commission to meet a particular situation where topographical or other
conditions made continuance or conformance to existing streets impractical.
(c)   Local street alignment.  The alignment of local streets shall be such
that their use by through traffic will be discouraged.
(d)   Arterial streets.  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or
proposed minor arterial street or principal arterial, the Commission may
require marginal access streets, reverse frontage with screen planting
contained in a non-access reservation along the rear property line, deep lots
with rear service alleys, or such other treatment as may be necessary for
adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation of
through and local traffic.
(e)   Certain rights-of-way.  Where a subdivision borders on or contains a
railroad right-of-way or limited access highway right-of-way, the Commission
may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-
of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land,
as for park purposes in residential districts, or for commercial or industrial
purposes in appropriate districts.  Such distances shall also be determined
with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade
separations.
(f)   Reserve strips.  Reserve strips controlling access to public streets
shall be prohibited except where approved by the Commission.
(g)   Street jogs.  Streets shall not be designed with jogs with centerline
offsets of less than 150 feet.
(h)   Reverse curve on certain streets.  A tangent at least 100 feet long shall
be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets.
(i)   Intersections.  Streets shall intersect as nearly as possible at right
angles.  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius
of 20 feet or a greater radius where the Commission may deem it necessary.
(j)   Right-of-way widths for public streets.  Right-of-way widths for public
streets shall be as shown in the general plan for the city and where not shown
therein shall be not less than as follows, except where excessive cuts or fills
will require additional right-of-way:
   Street            Right-of-way Width
   Principal arterial         100'
   Minor arterial              80'
   Collector              60'
   Local                 50'
(k)   Cul-de-sacs and residential subdivisions.  Cul-de-sacs and residential
subdivisions shall be designed in accordance with the following requirements:
   (1)   Subdivisions in districts designated for single-family use by the
zoning ordinance and with a single point of access to a collector, minor
arterial street or principal arterial shall not be designed to serve more than
60 dwelling units.  Appropriate road widths shall be provided in accordance
with Section 92-97(a).  Secondary emergency vehicle access shall be provided in
accordance with the fire code.
      In certain circumstances, a single-family residential subdivision
containing more than 60 lots that would utilize a single means of access may be
approved, upon determination by the Planning and Zoning Commission that the
subdivision is designed in a manner that will incorporate accepted urban design
principles relative to the design and arrangements of street and lots in order
to minimize negative traffic and safety impacts.  The developer shall submit
supporting information such as proposed estimated traffic volume based on
accepted ITE trip rates, location of nearest emergency response bases, and
details of any features of the subdivision intended to mitigate traffic or
emergency access problems.
   (2)   The length of a cul-de-sac (dead-end) street in a single family
subdivision is limited to 1,600 linear feet. In all other subdivisions, the
cul-de-sac shall not exceed 500 feet in length. Cul-de-sac street length shall
be measured from a point beginning at the intersection of the cul-de-sac street
with the center line of the street from which it extends and continuing
thereafter along the center line of the cul-de-sac street to the center point
of the turn-around at the end of the cul-de-sac street.
   (3)   Cul-de-sac streets that are 150 feet in length or longer shall be
designed at the closed end with a turn-around (cul-de-sac) having an outside
pavement diameter of a minimum of 95 feet and a street property line diameter
of a minimum of 117 feet.  Cul-de-sac streets that are less than 150 feet in
length shall be designed at the closed end with a turn-around having an outside
pavement diameter that is a minimum of 77 feet and a street property line
diameter that is a minimum of 100 feet.  For a cul-de-sac street of any length,
if a greater minimum outside pavement diameter or street property line diameter
is required by the fire code, as amended, the minimum diameter shall be as
specified in the fire code.  If an existing dead-end street with no cul-de-sac
meeting current standards stops at the proposed subdivision's boundary, and the
proposed subdivision is not going to extend the street, then the subdivider
shall construct a cul-de-sac meeting current standards.
(l)   Street grades.  Street grades shall be established with due regard to
topography, contemplated land use, adjacent facilities surrounding the land to
be subdivided, as well as the Master Drainage Plan.  The minimum street grade
shall be 0.70%.
(m)   Flood design.  The flood design section for streets shall be taken from
back of curb to back of curb, provided that in no case shall the height of
curbs for subdivisions be more than six inches.  The top of curb elevation for
streets with curbs shall not be below the 100-year floodplain elevation as
designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). The top-of-
pavement elevation for streets without curbs shall not be below the 100- year
floodplain elevation as designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency
(FEMA).
(n)   Stricter standards.  The City Engineer may require that a particular
street, portion of a street, or intersection meet stricter (higher) standards
than those set forth in this chapter if, in the professional opinion of the
City Engineer, such stricter standards are necessary based on a sight-distance
study and/or traffic impact analysis performed in accordance with the
requirements of Section 92-18 of this chapter.  Failure or refusal to comply
with any such stricter standards shall be grounds for disapproval of the plat.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 25, 9-12-02; Ord. No. 3304, § 2,
3-25-04; Ord. No. 3241, § 8, 8-28-03; Ord. No. 3441, § 5, 4-13-06)
Sec. 92-99.   Design standards for alleys.
Where public alleys are provided, they shall meet the following requirements:
(a)   The minimum width of pavement in a public alley shall be 20 feet and the
minimum width of the right-of-way for a public alley shall be 30 feet.
(b)   Public alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be
avoided, but where necessary, corners shall be cut off sufficiently to permit
safe vehicular movement.
(c)   Dead-end public alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if
unavoidable, shall be provided with adequate turn-around facilities at the
dead-end, as determined by the Commission.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3241, § 9, 8- 28-03)
Sec. 92-100.   Design standards for easements.
(a)   Easements required; width of same.  Easements across lots or centered on
rear and/or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and
shall be at least 15 feet wide.  The Commission may require a wider easement
width if more than one utility line is located in an easement, if a utility
line will have six feet or more of cover, or if deemed necessary by the City
Engineer.
(b)   Easements for drainage.  Where there is provided a storm water, drainage
or floodplain easement or right-of-way in accordance with Section 92-103 of
this chapter, said easement or right-of-way shall conform in width to the water
elevation of the 100-year flood, said flood being computed in accordance with
the development projected by the city’s future land use map.  Parallel streets
or parkways may be required in connection therewith.  Except as expressly
provided otherwise in this chapter, no structures shall be allowed within such
drainage or floodplain easements or rights-of-way.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 26, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-101.   Design standards for blocks.
(a)   The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due
regard to all of the following considerations:
   (1)   provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of
the type of use contemplated;
   (2)   zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimension;
   (3)   needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street
traffic; and
   (4)   limitations and opportunities of topography.
(b)   Blocks lengths shall not exceed 1,600 feet.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-102.   Design standards for lots.
(a)   The lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation and the minimum
building setback lines shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision
and for the type of development and use required under the zoning ordinance.
(b)   Corner lots for residential use shall have extra width to permit
appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets; provided,
however, that the City Planner may authorize such a corner lot to be of the
same standard width and length as other lots in the same subdivision if access
to the lot (driveway, etc) is restricted to the smaller of the two streets (the
street with the lower classification under the street classification system
used in this chapter) or to the street that is less traveled, as the City
Planner deems appropriate.
(c)   The subdivision of the land shall be such as to provide each lot with
satisfactory access to an existing public street.
(d)   Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where
essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic
arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation.
(e)   Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street
lines.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-103.   Design standards for drainage channels.
(a)   Drainage area map.  Along with each pre-submission proposal, a subdivider
shall provide a drainage area map showing the proposed project area as well as
adjacent areas affected by the subdivision.  All drainage calculations shall be
shown (or included in a separate report) and shall be in accordance with the
City of Longview Drainage Criteria and Erosion Control Manual, as approved and
hereafter implemented by the city.
(b)   Additional information.  Based on these drainage calculations, and as a
prerequisite to its approval, each pre-submission proposal shall contain within
its boundary all required drainage structures necessary to conform the platted
property to the Master Drainage Plan and the City of Longview Drainage Criteria
and Erosion Control Manual.  The drainage calculations/report shall show the
overall storm water impact for the land contained within the pre-submission
proposal. 
(c)   Drainage required.  Where a water course drainage way, channel or stream
is included in any part of, or is adjacent to the property to be subdivided, it
shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to either (1) improve said
natural drainage channel, if warranted by the Master Drainage Plan and the City
of Longview Drainage Criteria and Erosion Control Manual, according to the
standards set forth therein or (2) dedicate the future 100-year floodplain to
the city in a floodplain easement.  The City Engineer shall set forth
requirements to insure compatibility with the Master Drainage Plan.  The city
shall accept an adequate easement or right-of-way and thereafter maintain said
drainage improvement after the one year warranty period.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 27, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-104.   Design standards for parks and other dedicated open spaces.
Subdividers are encouraged to set aside land for parks and open space within
subdivisions.  Land dedicated for future use as a public park shall conform to
the needs identified in the city’s park, recreation, and open space master
plan.  Actual plans for parks and/or park facilities designated for public use
should be coordinated with the appropriate liaison with the city’s parks and
recreation department to assure compliance with current safety and design
standards.  Any area in a subdivision being designated “park” or “future park,”
with the intent of the area becoming a public park, shall have the approval of
the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board prior to submittal of the plat to the
Commission.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-105.   Design standards for sidewalks.
Sidewalks in residential areas where provided, shall be four feet in width and
comply with all applicable federal, state and local regulations.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-106.   Design standards for private streets.
Private streets shall be designed and constructed to meet the following minimum
standards:
(a)   The pavement width shall not be less than required by the fire code.
(b)   The minimum street section shall be either one and a half inches of Type
D asphalt with six inches of Type A Grade 2 Flexible Base on six inches of
scarified and recompacted subgrade, or one and a half inches of Type D asphalt
with six inches of Type C Grade 3 Flexible Base and BX 1100 Tensar Geogrid on
six inches of scarified and recompacted subgrade.
(c)   The Plasticity Index “(PI)” shall be determined for the native subgrade
soil.  If the “PI” is 25 or greater the subgrade shall be lime stabilized per a
geotechnical engineer’s recommendation.
(d)   Iron ore flex base meeting the TxDOT specifications listed above will be
approved for use for private streets.
(e)   All private street construction shall be in accordance with the latest
version of TxDOT's standard specifications.
(Ord. No. 3241, § 10, 8-28-03)
Sec. 92-107.   Drainage design standards for private streets.
Drainage systems for private streets shall be designed and constructed to meet
the following minimum standards:
(a)   Roadside ditches may be used instead of curb and gutter along private
streets if the lot density of the proposed subdivision is less than or equal to
three lots per acre. The lot density will be calculated by dividing the total
number of lots by the acreage of the subdivision outside of any floodplain.
(b)   When roadside ditches are used, they shall be designed and constructed
per Section 5.5.2 of the City of Longview Drainage Criteria and Erosion Control
Manual with the exception that the 25-year storm may be used instead of the
100-year storm for the design discharge.
(c)   If curb and gutter is required or used, then the drainage standards will
be the same as for public streets.
(Ord. No. 3241, § 11, 8-28-03)
Secs. 92-108 - 92-115.  Reserved.
Article VII.
Special Floodplain Provisions
Sec. 92-116.   Purpose; applicability.
The purpose of this article is as follows:
(a)   to regulate the subdivision and/or development of flood-prone areas
within the corporate limits of the city, in order to promote the general
health, welfare and safety of the community;
(b)   to require that each subdivision lot in a flood-prone area be provided
with a safe building site with adequate access and that public facilities which
serve such uses be designed and installed to preclude flood damage at the time
of initial construction; and
(c)   to protect individuals from buying lands which are unsuitable for use
because of flood hazards by prohibiting the subdivision and/or development of
unprotected flood-prone areas.
The provisions of this article shall apply only to a subdivision of land
containing one or more flood-prone areas.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-117.   Definitions.
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   Flood-prone area.  A relatively flat or low land area adjoining a stream,
river, or watercourse, which is subject to partial or complete inundation; or
any area subject to the unusual rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters
from any source.
   Flood-proofing. Any combination of structural and non-structural additions,
changes, or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to
real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities,
structures and their contents.  “Flood-proofed” shall mean provided with such a
combination of additions, changes or adjustments.
   Floodway.  The channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land
areas required to carry and discharge a flood of a given magnitude.
   Regulatory flood.  A flood having an average frequency of occurrence on the
order of once in 100 years, although the flood may occur in any year.
   Regulatory flood elevation.  The 100-year flood elevation based upon the
information contained In the official flood insurance study.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-118.   City liability.
The grant of a permit or approval of a subdivision and/or land development plan
containing a flood-prone area or areas shall not constitute a representation,
guarantee, or warranty of any kind by the city or by any official or employee
of the city of the practicability or safety of the proposed use and shall
create no liability upon the city, its officials or employees.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-119.   Pre-submission proposal requirements.
The following information shall be additionally required as part of the
presubmission proposal and shall be prepared by a professional engineer or
professional land surveyor:
(a)   Name of engineer, surveyor or other qualified person responsible for
providing the information required in this section.
(b)   A map showing the location of the proposed subdivision and/or land
development with respect to the city’s flood-prone areas including information
on, but not limited to, the regulatory flood elevations, boundaries of flood-
prone areas, proposed lots and sites, fills, flood or erosion protective
facilities and areas subject to special deed restrictions.
(c)   Where the subdivision and/or land development lies partially or
completely in the flood-prone area, or where the subdivision and/or land
development borders on the flood-prone area, the pre-submission proposal map
shall include detailed information giving the location and elevation of
proposed streets, public utilities and building sites.
(d)   A map showing the exact location and elevation of all proposed buildings,
structures, streets and public utilities to be constructed in any flood-prone
area.  All maps shall show contours at intervals of two feet and identify
accurately the boundaries of the flood-prone area.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3241, § 12, 8-28-03)
Sec. 92-120.   Plat requirements.
The following information shall be additionally required as part of the plat
and shall be prepared by a professional engineer or professional land surveyor:
(a)   All information required for the submission of the pre-submission
proposal incorporating any changes requested by the City Engineer.
(b)   A map showing the exact location and elevation of all proposed buildings,
structures, streets and public utilities to be constructed in any flood-prone
area.  All maps shall show contours at intervals of two feet and identify
accurately the boundaries of the flood-prone area.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3241, § 13, 8-28-03)
Sec. 92-121.   Design standards and improvements.
(a)   Platting of land within flood-prone area.  Where not prohibited by this
or any other laws or ordinances, land located in a flood-prone area may be
platted for development with the provision that the subdivider construct all
buildings and structures to preclude flood in accordance with this and any
other laws and ordinances regulating such development.
(b)   Prohibited increase of regulatory flood elevation. No subdivision and/or
land development, or part thereof, shall be approved if the proposed
development and/or improvements will, individually or collectively, increase
the regulatory flood elevation more than one foot at any point.
(c)   Building sites for residential uses.  Building sites for residences or
any other type of dwelling or accommodation shall not be permitted in any
floodway.  Sites for these uses may be permitted outside the floodway area, if
the sites or dwelling units are elevated to a height at least two feet above
the elevation of the 100-year flood.  The fill area shall extend out laterally
for a distance of at least 15 feet beyond the limits of the proposed
structures.
(d)    Building sites for non-residential uses.  Building sites for structures
or buildings other than for residential uses shall also not be permitted in any
floodway area.  Also such sites for structures or buildings outside the
floodway shall be protected as provided for in subsection (c) of this section. 
However, the Commission may allow the subdivision and/or development of areas
or sites for commercial and industrial uses at an elevation less than one foot
above the regulatory flood if the subdivider otherwise protects the area to
that height or assures that the buildings or structures will be flood-proofed
at least up to that height.
(e)   Authority of City Engineer.  If the City Engineer determines that only a
part of a proposed plat can be safely developed, development shall be limited
to that part and shall proceed consistently with the City Engineer’s
determination.
(f)   Additional controls.  When a subdivider does not intend to develop the
plat himself/herself and the City Engineer determines that additional controls
are required to ensure safe development, the Commission, upon the
recommendation of the City Engineer, may require the subdivider to impose
appropriate deed restrictions on the land.  Such deed restrictions shall be
inserted in every deed and noted on every recorded plat.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-122.   Sewer facilities.
(a)   Flood-proofing required.  All sanitary sewer systems located in any
flood-prone area, whether public or private, shall be flood-proofed up to a
point of one foot above the regulatory flood elevation.
(b)   Prohibition in certain areas.  The Commission, based on the
recommendation of the City Engineer, may prohibit installation of disposal
facilities requiring soil absorption systems where such systems will not
function due to high ground water, flooding, or unsuitable soil
characteristics.  The Commission, based on the recommendation of the City
Engineer, may require a note on the face of the plat and in any deed or
conveyance that soil absorption fields are prohibited in designated areas.
(c)   Prescription of waste disposal methods.  The Commission, based on the
recommendation of the City Engineer, may prescribe adequate methods for waste
disposal.  If a sanitary sewer system is located on or near the proposed
subdivision and/or land development, the Commission shall require the
subdivider to provide sewage facilities to connect to this system where
practical and shall prescribe the procedures to be followed by the subdivider
in connecting to the system, as recommended by the City Engineer.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-123.   Water facilities.
All water systems located in any flood-prone area, whether public or private,
shall be flood-proofed to a point one foot above the regulatory flood
elevation.  If there is an existing public water supply system on or near the
subdivision, the City Engineer shall require the subdivider to connect to this
system where practical, and shall prescribe the procedures to be followed by
the subdivider in connecting to the system.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Secs. 92-124 - 92-135.  Reserved.
Article VIII.
Enforcement
Sec. 92-136.   Connection of utilities.
(a)   Utility service connection, general rule.  Neither the city nor any other
person, firm or corporation that provides water, sewer service, electricity,
natural gas or other fuel service, telecommunication service, cable television
service or any other utility service shall make any connections of any utility
service to any residence, business, building or other structure upon any
subdivided area, the subdivision of which has not been accomplished in
accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter.
(b)   Exception, temporary service.  In a subdivided area that has not been
subdivided in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, the
City Engineer may authorize the provision of such temporary water service,
electric service and other utility services as are necessary or appropriate for
the completion of the subdivision in a manner that complies with the
requirements of this chapter.  The City Engineer may order the suspension or
termination of such temporary service for any violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-137.   Authority of the City Attorney.
The City Attorney is hereby authorized and it shall be the duty of the City
Attorney without further authorization of the City Council to undertake, by all
legal means appropriate or necessary, the enforcement of this chapter,
including, but not limited to enforcement in municipal court, filing of
appropriate civil actions in courts of appropriate jurisdiction, defending the
city from suit if suit is taken to appeal any action of the city, and any other
action authorized by law.  In addition to any other authorization provided
herein, the City Attorney is hereby expressly authorized and requested to take
any and all actions authorized by Section 212.018 of the Texas Local Government
Code in order to prevent, stop, remedy, and/or recover damages for any
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)
Sec. 92-138.   Criminal penalties; no culpable mental state required.
Violations of any provision or provisions of this chapter shall constitute a
misdemeanor and shall be punishable in accordance with Section 1-4 of this
code. Each day or portion of a day during which such a violation continues
shall be considered a separate offense. The City Council hereby dispenses with
the requirement of establishing a culpable mental state in order to prove a
violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02; Ord. No. 3154, § 28, 9-12-02)
Sec. 92-139.   Effects of remedies.
(a)   Remedies not exclusive.  The remedies and penalties set out in this
chapter are intended to be non-exclusive; that is, they shall be construed to
not exclude the city from seeking any and all remedies at law or equity to
which the city may be entitled under state law or otherwise, and the remedies
as set out herein shall be considered in addition to and cumulative of such
remedies as set out under state and/or federal law.
(b)   Conviction not a bar.  No conviction or convictions under any penal
provisions of this chapter or any of the statutes of the state shall ever be
considered as any bar to any injunctive or other legal relief, remedy, right or
power existing in the city to enforce the application and provisions of this
chapter by virtue of the Constitution and Laws of the State of Texas and the
Charter of this city.
(c)   Municipal court remedies preserved.  Remedies set out in this article
shall not affect or be construed to affect the ability of the city to proceed
under the criminal jurisdiction of the city municipal court.
(Ord. No. 3124, § 3, 5-23-02)

Reserved
