9-107   Interpretations and Definitions
   A.   Applicability
      This section applies to Section 9-108, Section 9-109, Section 9-110,
Section 9-111 and Section 9-112 of this ordinance.
   B.   Interpretation
      Unless context clearly requires otherwise, the following rules of
interpretation apply to each section to which this section applies:
      1.   The provisions of each section constitute minimum requirements. 
Where any section imposes greater restrictions than those of any other law, the
greater restrictions shall prevail.  Where another law imposes greater
restrictions, the greater restrictions shall prevail.
      2.   The specific shall control the general.
      3.   In the case of any conflict between the text of a section and the
implications of any chart, graph, illustration or table in that section, the
text shall control.
      4.   The words "shall," "will," and "must" are always mandatory and are
not discretionary.
      5.   The word "may" is permissive and discretionary.
      6.   The words "building" and "structure" shall be construed as though
followed by the words, "or portion thereof."
      7.   The word "occupied" shall be construed as though followed by the
words "or intended, arranged or designed to be occupied."
      8.   The "rear," "side," and "front" portions of a lot shall be
determined with reference to the illustrations contained in the Appendix to
this ordinance.
      9.   Where a word has not been defined, the standard dictionary
definition shall apply.
      10.   In determining whether a zoning use or district is more intensive
or less intensive than the use or district to which it is compared, the
following rules apply:
         a.   The zoning districts used in this ordinance, from least intensive
to most intensive, are as follows:  A, SF-1, SF-2, SF-3, SF-4, SF-5, TF-1, TF-
2, TF-3, MF-1, MF-2, MF-3, O, NS, GR, C-1, C-2, CB, I-1, and I-2.  A PD shall
be classified based on the most intensive use allowed in that particular PD.
         b.   A more intensive use is a use that is allowed in fewer zoning
districts than the use to which it is being compared.
         c.   A less intensive use is a use that is allowed in more zoning
districts than the use to which it is compared.
         d.   Any non-residential use is considered to be more intensive than a
residential use, regardless of whether the non-residential use is allowed in TF
or SF zoning districts.  For purposes of this subsection, a "residential use"
is any of the following:  a one-family dwelling, an accessory use associated
with a specific one-family dwelling, a two-family dwelling, or an accessory use
associated with a specific two-family dwelling.  For purposes of this
subsection, any use that is not a "residential use" is a "non-residential use."
      11.   The following abbreviations shall refer to the following zoning
districts as said districts are set forth in this ordinance:
         "A"   Agricultural Zoning District
         "SF"   Single-Family Residential (SF-1, SF-2, SF-3, SF-4 & SF-5)
Zoning Districts
         "TF"   Two-Family Residential (TF-1, TF-2 & TF-3) Zoning Districts
         "MF"   Multi-Family Residential (MF-1, MF-2 & MF-3) Zoning Districts
         "O"   Office Zoning District
         "NS"   Neighborhood Services Zoning District
         "GR"   General Retail Zoning District
         "C"   Commercial (C-1 & C-2) Zoning Districts
         "CB"   Central Business Zoning District
         "I" or "Industrial"   Industrial (I-1 & I-2) Zoning Districts
         "P"   Parking Zoning District
         "PD"   Planned Development District
      12.   Container class sizes and measurements, as well as the sizes and
measurements of any plant materials described in terms of container class shall
be determined with reference to the American Standard for Nursery Stock (ANSI
Z60.1-2004), approved May 12, 2004, by the American Nursery and Landscape
Association.
   C.   Definitions
      Unless context clearly requires otherwise, the following words shall have
the meanings set forth in this section:
         Barrier:  A device/treatment controlling the management, circulation,
separation, or direction of traffic, including but not limited to, wheel stops,
raised islands, dividers or barricades.
         Berm:  An earthen mound designed to provide visual interest, screening
or decreased noise.
         Buffer yard:  Open spaces, landscaped areas, fences, walls, berms or
any combination thereof, or of similar materials, used to physically separate
or screen more intensive uses of a lot from less intensive uses (whether
existing or contemplated by this ordinance) on adjoining lots to physically
shield or block noise, lights or other nuisances generated by the more
intensive use and affecting the less intensive use.  The more intensive use
shall bear the responsibility of providing required buffering.
         Building permit:  A permit issued pursuant to the building code
adopted in Article II to Chapter 19 of the Longview City Code.
         Caliper:  Diameter of a predominant tree trunk measured six (6) inches
above grade for trees four (4) inches in diameter or less.  For trees with
larger diameter, the caliper shall be the measurement of the tree diameter four
and one-half (4 1/2) feet above grade.
         Canopy tree:  Any self-supporting woody plant with one well-defined
trunk and a distinct and definite formed crown, which attains a height of at
least thirty (30) feet above grade.
         Certificate of occupancy:  The certificate of occupancy issued by the
Building Official of the City of Longview pursuant to the official building
code adopted in Article II to Chapter 19 of the Longview City Code.
         Container class:  The term "container class" shall have the meaning
given to that term in the American Standard for Nursery Stock (ANSI Z60.1-
2004), approved May 12, 2004, by the American Nursery and Landscape
Association.
         Development:  Any structure or use or the construction, reconstruction
or enlargement of any structure or use.
         Existing Tree:  Any canopy tree or non-canopy tree that is present on
a lot prior to development.
         Floodplain:  The term "floodplain" shall have the meaning assigned to
that term in Section 43-1 of the Longview City Code.
         Floodway:  The term "floodway" shall have the meaning assigned to that
term in Section 43-1 of the Longview City Code.
         Grass:  Any of the numerous grass species that will attain a thick
green cover of turf over the available soil area.
         Ground cover:  Any woody or herbaceous plant that effectively shades
sod that will not generally attain a height above two (2) feet.
         Landscaped area:  An area devoted to and which may consist of plant
materials, water forms, planters, brick, stone, aggregate and other materials
customarily utilized for landscaping purposes, or any combination of these
items, but not including the use of smooth concrete or asphalt and like
materials.
         Landscape plan:  The plan submitted to satisfy the requirements of
Section 9-112 of this ordinance.
         Landscaping:  Changing, rearranging or adding to the original plant
materials or scenery of land, including the reshaping of the land by moving
earth, preservation of original plant materials or addition of new plant
materials, or any combination of these treatments.
         Lawful non-conforming development:  A development lawfully established
prior to the effective date of a section that fails to comply with the
requirements of the section.
         Lot:  The real property included within the boundaries of any lot
approved and recorded in the plat records of the county of jurisdiction, or an
unplatted tract or parcel of land as described and recorded in the real
property records of the county of jurisdiction.
         Non-canopy tree:  Any self-supporting woody plant with one or more
well-defined trunks, which will attain a height of at least fifteen (15) feet,
but not including a canopy tree.
         Parkway:  That portion of the public right-of-way located between the
edge of the pavement (or curb) of any public street (which is not an alley) and
the boundary of the public right-of-way.
         Plant materials:  Living trees, shrubs, vines, grass, ground covers,
cactus and flowering annuals, biennials and perennials.
         Pre-submission proposal:  The pre-submission proposal required by
Chapter 92 of the Longview City Code.
         Protected area:  An area barricaded so that construction practices in
the field will protect existing trees and other plant materials from compaction
of soil, changes in grade, erosion, and damage from vehicles and construction
machinery.
         Protected tree:  A tree for which a temporary or permanent barrier was
constructed to protect the tree from damage during construction and/or from
normal site usage and vehicle movements.
         Screening:  A method of visually shielding one abutting or nearby
structure or use from another by fencing, walls, berms and/or densely planted
plant materials, or any combination of these methods.
         Shrub:  A woody perennial plant distinguished from herbaceous plants
by its persistent woody stem and from a tree by a mature height of less than
fifteen (15) feet and having no distinctive elevated crown of foliage.
         Street yard:  The area of lot located between the street right(s)-of-
way line(s) and each building that faces the said street right(s)-of-way.
         Unprotected tree:  A tree that has no specially constructed protection
barriers to prevent damage due to the construction or normal vehicular
movement.
9-108   Buffer Yard Requirements
   A.   Applicability
      1.   Where a side or rear lot line abuts or adjoins a lot with a less
intensive zoning designation, buffer yards are required as set forth in Table
9-108.
      2.   For uses that do not require Industrial zoning, any areas used as
buffer yards and any landscaping in said areas that otherwise complies with the
requirements of this article will be counted as landscaped areas and as
landscaping, respectively, for purposes of satisfying the requirements of
Section 9-111 of this ordinance.  For uses that require Industrial zoning, any
areas used as buffer yards and any landscaping in said areas will not be
counted as landscaped areas and as landscaping, respectively, for purposes of
satisfying the requirements of Section 9-111 of this ordinance, and the
requirements of this section shall be in addition to those of Section 9-111.
      3.   Buffer yards are not required on that portion of a lot located
immediately adjacent to another lot occupied by a lawful non-conforming
development.
      4.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to a lawful non-
conforming development.  However, except as expressly provided otherwise in
this section, an abandonment, expansion, destruction or change in use of a
lawful non-conforming development shall cause the lawful non-conforming
development to lose its status as a lawful non-conforming development and said
development shall thereafter be subject to the requirements of this section. 
For purposes of this section, "destruction" of a lawful non-conforming
development means damage by fire, explosion, flood, tornado, or similar
catastrophic event where the cost of repair exceeds fifty (50) percent of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      5.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to the
reconstruction of a lawful non-conforming development due to damage by fire,
explosion, flood, tornado, or similar catastrophic event if the damage to the
lawful non-conforming development does not exceed fifty (50) percent of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      6.   This section does not apply to any lots located within the Central
Business district (CB).
      7.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a one-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any).
      8.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a two-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any).
      9.   This section does not apply to any lot on which there is no
development.
      10.   This section does not apply to expansion, reconstruction, or
renovation of an existing development if the expansion, reconstruction, or
renovation will not do any of the following:
         a.   increase the total square footage of a building and its
associated parking lot by twenty-five percent (25%) or more; or
         b.   increase the number of stories of a building and increase the
total square footage of the building by twenty-five percent (25%) or more; or
         c.   result in a more intensive use on the lot.
      11.   The requirements of this section do not apply to that portion of a
parking lot that existed before the effective date of this section.
      12.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section shall apply in each instance where a one-family dwelling or a two-
family dwelling exists in a zoning district other than SF or TF and a change in
occupancy results in a more intensive use.
      13.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a lot is rezoned from either SF or TF to
a zoning classification other than SF or TF and the lot or any portion of the
lot is converted to a use that is not allowed in either SF or TF zoning
districts.
      14.   This section does not apply to any excluded lot area, as the term
"excluded lot area" is used in Section 9-112 of this ordinance.
   B.   Buffer Yards Required
      Buffer yards shall be required in accordance with the following
regulations:
      1.   Buffer yards shall be installed on those sides and rear lot line(s)
that adjoin or abut a less intensive land use/zoning district for the entire
length of said common boundary with the less intensive use or zoning district. 
Those instances where buffer yards are required are described in Table 9-108. 
Buffer yards shall not extend into the public right-of-way.
      2.   To determine if buffer yards are required, as well as the type of
buffer yard required between adjacent or adjoining properties, the following
procedure shall be followed:
         a.   Identify the zoning of the subject lot and the zoning of each
adjacent lot,
         b.   Determine if buffer yards are required, as well as the specific
requirements (if any) for affected side or rear lot line(s), or portions
thereof, from Table 9-108.  Existing plant materials, fences and similar
features on the subject site may be counted as contributing to satisfying the
buffer yard requirement.  Required buffer yards are to be provided independent
of similar materials located on adjacent properties.
         c.   The buffer yard requirements may be satisfied by any one of the
methods depicted in Table 9-108, except that a fence shall be provided in all
instances where an I, C, GR or MF zoning district abuts a lot zoned SF or TF.
   C.   Buffer Yard Requirements
      1.   Should a developed use propose to become a more intensive use via a
rezoning request, the Planning and Zoning Commission and City Council may,
during the review process, determine if additional buffering is needed, and if
so, the extent and type required in addition to those in Table 9-108.
      2.   The City Planner shall have the authority to reduce the buffer yard
requirement to a width no less than five (5) feet in those instances where an
adjoining lot is located in a floodplain that prevents and/or severely limits
development of said lot.
      3.   The applicability of buffer yard requirements for unlisted uses, or
for a new development located adjacent to an unlisted use, shall be determined
by the City Planner.  In those instances when a permitted non-residential land
use, such as a school, church or utility, applies for a building permit to
locate in a TF or SF zoning district, the City Planner shall observe the
general concepts depicted in Table 9-108 to form the basis for determining
applicable buffer yard requirements.  When any party is aggrieved by the
decision of the City Planner as to the classification of unlisted uses for
buffering purposes an appeal may be made to the Planning and Zoning Commission
as provided in Section 8-300 of this ordinance.
      4.   Required buffer yards shall be landscaped with grass, shrubs, or
trees, or in combination with other suitable ground cover or screening
materials (such as, but not limited to, approved fences and berms), subject to
the Landscape Plan requirements of Section 9-112.  Required buffer yards shall
remain as open space, free from all structures, except that permitted
driveways, pedestrian walkways, flagpoles and similar appurtenant structures
may be located in required buffer yards.  Off-street parking areas, dumpsters,
drive-through window driving lanes, order window speakers, or interior access
drives/maneuvering areas shall not be permitted in required buffer yards.
      5.   Wheel stops, curbs, or similar barriers shall be utilized to
prohibit parking and car overhang into required buffer yard planting areas. 
Accepted professional landscaping standards shall be utilized to ensure that
the area within vegetation drip lines is not covered with impervious materials
to a degree that would adversely affect landscaping in required buffer yards.
      6.   The use of loose stone, rock, gravel or other decorative chips and
like materials may be utilized as a landscaping accent in buffer yards, but
shall be limited to only twenty percent (20%) of the area of the required
buffer, and must be supplemented with other landscaping materials in accordance
with the requirements of this ordinance.
      7.   When a fence is required to satisfy buffer yard regulations, the
fence may be comprised of a berm, solid year-round vegetative screen, masonry
wall or wooden fencing, or a combination of these treatments, provided that a
minimum height of said opaque screen provides one hundred percent (100%) year-
round screening and has a minimum height of six (6) feet, as measured from
grade.  In the event that a solid vegetative screen is utilized, the vegetative
screen shall provide year-round screening and have a minimum height of three
(3) feet at the time of installation and a minimum height of six (6) feet at
the time of maturity.
      8.   Screening fences installed to comply with the requirements of this
section shall be constructed of conventional, opaque fencing materials to be
approved by the City Planner.  Acceptable screening fences include, but are not
limited to, solid wood fences, made of treated pine, cedar or redwood, or
masonry walls.  Unacceptable materials include, but are not limited to,
plywood, corrugated steel sheets and chain link fences with weave.  All
required fences shall be maintained in a good condition.
      9.   In the case of multi-storied buildings, an additional five (5) feet
of side and rear yard buffer depth shall be added for every story above one (1)
with a maximum buffer width not to exceed 30 feet.
      10.   Existing plant materials may be retained to satisfy the provisions
of this section, provided that natural areas proposed to be retained are
documented on submitted landscape plans and preserved at all times thereafter. 
The site development plan and landscape plan submitted for permits shall
include information detailing the measures to ensure that these natural areas
will not be affected by the development of the lot or by the use of the lot.
   D.   Compliance Required
      1.   A sufficiently detailed site plan shall be submitted in accordance
with the requirements of Section 7-200 and Section 9-112 demonstrating
compliance with the requirements of said sections.
      2.   A certificate of occupancy shall be withheld until compliance with
all applicable requirements of this section is attained.
Click_here_to_view_Table_9-108.
9-109   Refuse Collection Facility Screening Requirements
   A.   Applicability
      1.   For purposes of this section, a refuse collection facility is
defined as a receptacle intended for the disposal, collection or temporary
storage of unsorted solid waste products and refuse outdoors.  A refuse
collection facility includes, without limitation, trash dumpsters and trash
compactors.  The therm does not include a dumpster located on a lot with an
active building permit for the sole purpose of collecting solid waste products
and refuse that result from construction occurring on said lot during the
effective period of the active building permit.
      2.   All refuse collection facilities located in SF, TF, MF, O, NS, P,
GR, C, CB, I, and PD zoning districts, shall be screened from view of public
streets and adjoining properties in accordance with the regulations contained
in this section.
      3.   This section shall apply to each and every refuse collection
facility without regard to whether the refuse collection facility existed at
its present location prior to the effective date of this section.
      4.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section shall apply in each instance where a one-family dwelling or a two-
family dwelling exists in a zoning district other than SF or TF and a change in
occupancy results in a more intensive unit.
      5.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a lot is rezoned from either SF or TF to
a zoning classification other than SF or TF and the lot or any portion of the
lot is converted to a use that is not allowed in either SF or TF zoning
districts.
   B.   Screening/Orientation Requirements
      1.   Each refuse collection facility shall be screened with opaque
screening such that the refuse collection facility is not visible from the
public right-of-way and is not visible from any adjacent area that is zoned SF,
TF, or MF pursuant to this ordinance.  All screening used to comply with the
requirements of this section shall have a height equal to or greater than the
height of the refuse collection facility screened and shall otherwise comply
with this section.
      2.   Screening fences installed to comply with the requirements of this
section shall be constructed of conventional, opaque fencing materials to be
approved by the City Planner.  Acceptable screening fences include, but are not
limited to, solid wood fences, made of treated pine, cedar or redwood, or
masonry walls.  Unacceptable materials include, but are not limited to,
plywood, corrugated steel sheets and chain link fences with weave.  All
required fences shall be maintained in a good condition.
      3.   Solid vegetative screens may be utilized to screen dumpsters
provided that a minimum height of said opaque screen provides one hundred
percent (100%) year-round screening.  The vegetative screen shall have a
minimum height of three (3) feet at the time of installation and a minimum
height of six (6) feet at the time of maturity.
      4.   The City Planner may authorize the use of unconventional opaque
fencing materials to satisfy the requirements of this section if the fencing
materials so authorized match existing or proposed building facades.
      5.   Refuse collection facilities shall be located in the rear fifty
percent (50%) of the lot where practical, as determined by the City Planner in
accordance with the Appendix to this ordinance.
   C.   Compliance Required
      1.   The location of each refuse collection facility and the manner in
which each refuse collection facility is to be screened shall be clearly
delineated and described on the site plan submitted in accordance with the
requirements of Section 7-200 and the site plan shall demonstrate compliance
with this section.
      2.   A certificate of occupancy shall be withheld until compliance with
applicable requirements of this section is attained.
9-110   Screening Requirements
   A.   Screening Required
      In the zoning districts where outdoor display, storage and sales is
permitted, such outdoor display, storage, or sale of new or used goods, junk,
materials, merchandise or vehicles shall be prohibited, unless said items are
displayed, stored or sold in accordance with the requirements of one of the
following subsections:
      1.   Other than temporary display, storage or sale, as defined below,
items displayed, stored or sold outdoors shall be screened from the general
public by a fence having a minimum height of six (6) feet from grade. 
Screening fences installed to comply with the requirements of this section
shall be constructed of conventional, opaque fencing materials to be approved
by the City Planner.  Acceptable screening fences include, but are not limited
to, solid wood fences, made of treated pine, cedar or redwood, or masonry
walls.  Unacceptable materials include, but are not limited to, plywood,
corrugated steel sheets and chain link fences with weave.  All required fences
shall be maintained in a good condition.  Items stored, displayed, or sold
behind said fence shall be limited to a height from grade that is one foot less
than the height of the fence.
      2.   Temporary outdoor display, storage or sale, in the context of this
subsection, shall be defined as the keeping of any new or used goods, junk,
inventory, raw materials, merchandise, vehicles, or other items outdoors
without the screening required in subsection (A)(1) of this section for the
sale, display or storage of said goods or other items.  Temporary outdoor
display, storage or sale shall be subject to compliance with each fo the
following requirements:
         a.   The area used for temporary outdoor display, storage or sale
shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the total interior floor display area
of the adjacent sales building.
         b.   Temporary outdoor display, storage or sale is exclusively limited
to that portion of the site directly adjacent to the primary storefront, and
shall not infringe upon required parking spaces or a driveway maneuvering area
and shall not extend along the sides of the sales building.  The primary
storefront shall be defined as that portion of the sales building where the
main entrance is located and between the front lot line(s) and the front wall
(s) of building(s) on said lot.
         c.   Temporary outdoor display, storage or sale shall be permitted
only during regular business hours.  Items shall be stored indoors at all other
times.  Regular building hours shall be defined as between the hours of 7:00
a.m. and 9:00 p.m., or the actual hours of operation of the business, whichever
is shorter.
         d.   Areas used for temporary outdoor display, storage or sale shall
be maintained in a neat and orderly manner and shall comply with all other
applicable City ordinances.
         e.   The provisions of this subsection (2) shall apply to both
permanent and temporary vendors.
   B.   Applicability
      1.   This section does not apply to the following:
         a.   the sale, lease or service of automobiles, trucks, boats,
motorcycles, motor homes, vacation travel trailers or recreational vehicles;
         b.   the sale or rental of construction equipment and farm equipment;
         c.   Christmas tree sales;
         d.   nursery plants and seasonal lawn/garden supplies;
         e.   building construction materials and supplies; and
         f.   outdoor display, storage or sales within the Central Business
district (CB).
      2.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section shall apply in each instance where a one-family dwelling or a two-
family dwelling exists in a zoning district other than SF or TF and a change in
occupancy results in a more intensive use.
      3.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a lot is rezoned from either SF or TF to
a zoning classification other than SF or TF and the lot or any portion of the
lot is converted to a use that is not allowed in either SF or TF zoning
districts.
   C.   General Outdoor Storage, Display and/or Sales Requirements
      1.   Items displayed, stored or sold outdoors shall not be located within
a required buffer yard or required landscaped area.
      2.   Items shall not be displayed, stored or sold outdoors in any manner
that impedes or interferes with access to or from the site or circulation or
parking on the site.
   D.   Compliance Required
      1.   The location of required screening fences, as well as information
demonstrating compliance with all requirements of this section, shall be
clearly delineated and described on the landscape/site plan(s) submitted when
applying for a building permit.
      2.   A certificate of occupancy shall be withheld until compliance with
all applicable requirements of this section is attained.
9-111   Landscaping Requirements
   A.   Applicability
      1.   This section does not apply to lots located within the Central
Business district (CB).
      2.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a one-family dwelling or a two-family
dwelling exists in a zoning district other than SF or TF and a change in
occupancy results in a more intensive use.
      3.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a lot is rezoned from either SF or TF to
a  zoning classification other than SF or TF and the lot or any portion of the
lot is converted to a use that is not allowed in either SF or TF zoning
districts.
      4.   This section does not apply to any excluded lot area, as the term
"excluded lot area" is used in Section 9-112 of this ordinance.
      5.   The requirements of this section shall not apply ot a lawful non-
conforming development.  However, except as expressly provided otherwise in
this section, an abandonment, expansion, destruction or change in use of a
lawful non-conforming development shall cause the lawful non-conforming
development to lose its status as a lawful non-conforming development and said
development shall thereafter be subject to the requirements of this section. 
For purposes of this section, "destruction" of a lawful non-conforming
development means damage by fire, explosion, flood, tornado, or similar
catastrophic event where the cost of repair exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      6.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to the
reconstruction of a lawful non-conforming development due to damage by fire,
explosion, flood, tornado, or similar catastrophic event if the damage to the
lawful non-conforming development does not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      7.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a one-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any) as of the effective date of
this section as long as the lot continues to be occupied by the same one-family
dwelling.
      8.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a two-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any) as of the effective date of
this section as long as the lot continues to be occupied by the same two-family
dwelling.
      9.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a one-
family dwelling in which the owner resides and its accessory uses (if any).
      10.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a two-
family dwelling in which the owner resides and its accessory uses (if any).
      11.   This section does not apply to any lot on which there is no
development.
      12.   This section does not apply to an expansion of an existing
development if the expansion will not do any of the following:
         a.   increase the total square footage of a building and its
associated parking lot by twenty-five percent (25%) or more; or
         b.   increase the number of stories of a a building and increase the
total square footage of the building by twenty-five (25%) or more; or
         c.   include the construction of a new building unconnected to any
existing building.
      13.   The requirements of this section do not apply to that portion of a
parking lot that existed before the effective date of this section.
   B.   Landscape Requirements
      1.   Except as expressly provided otherwise in this section, the
following requirements apply to each lot and each development in the city:
         a.   The landscaping requirements shall be determined by the total
square footage of the lot less any area exempted by phased development or
classification as floodway as set forth in this section.  The developer shall
install, protect, and maintain landscaping based on a percentage of the total
lot area as set forth in this section.
         b.   The minimum required landscaped area shall be ten percent (10%)
of the total lot area, except for uses requiring Industrial zoning.
         c.   Uses requiring Industrial zoning shall comply with the following:
            1.   The minimum required landscaped area shall be five percent
(5%) of the total lot area.
            2.   One hundred percent (100%) of the required landscaped area
shall be located in the street yard.
            3.   When a lot abuts more than one street, landscaping shall be
evenly dispersed between each street yard.
         d.   For uses other than those requiring Industrial zoning, a lot
abutting only one street shall have a minimum of thirty percent (30%) of the
landscaped area located in the street yard, and the remaining percentage of
landscaping shall be evenly dispersed throughout the lot.
         e.   For uses other than those requiring Industrial zoning, a lot
abutting exactly two streets shall have a minimum of sixty percent (60%) of the
landscaped area located in the front street yards evenly dispersed on each
frontage, and the remaining percentage of landscaping shall be evenly dispersed
throughout the lot.
         f.   For uses other than those requiring Industrial zoning, a lot
abutting three or more streets shall have landscaping evenly dispersed between
each street yard.
         g.   Parking areas on lots with parking spaces adjacent to ROW or
front lot lines shall have a minimum setback of five (5) feet between the
parking area and the ROW or front lot line, and the setback area shall be
landscaped area.
         h.   For uses requiring Industrial zoning, required landscaped areas
shall contain a minimum of one (1) tree per seven thousand (7,000) square feet,
or fraction thereof,  of total lot area.  Trees planted to satisfy this
requirement shall be a minimum size of container class #10.
         i.   For uses requiring Industrial zoning, required landscaped areas
shall contain a minimum of two (2) shrubs per seven thousand (7,000) square
feet, or fraction thereof, of total lot area.  Shrubs planted to satisfy this
requirement shall be a minimum size of container class #3.
         j.   Except as otherwise specified by this section, required
landscaped areas shall contain a minimum of one (1) tree per three thousand
five hundred (3,500) square feet, or fraction thereof, of total lot area. 
Trees planted to satisfy this requirement shall be a minimum size of container
class #10.
         k.   Except as otherwise specified by this section, required
landscaped areas shall contain a minimum of two (2) shrubs per three thousand
five hundred (3,500) square feet, or fraction thereof of total lot area. 
Shrubs planted to satisfy this requirement shall be a minimum size of container
class #3.
         l.   Existing canopy trees may be preserved to fulfill the tree
planting regulations above if such trees are in a healthy and growing condition
and are protected in compliance with all applicable provisions of this
section.  Trees counted for preservation are applied with the following ratio
(where the number immediately to the right of the colon in the table below
represents the number of required trees that may be replaced by one existing
tree of the corresponding caliper specified in the left column of the table):
 
Existing Tree Caliper Ratio (existing: required)
1" - 6"               1:1
> than 6" - 12"       1:2
> than 12"            1:3
         m.   The City Planner may allow landscape preservation credit for
trees with a caliper less than 1 inch, such as for a stand of trees, if the
trees are protected in compliance with all applicable provisions of this
section.
         n.   A maximum of fifty percent (50%) of the trees planted or
protected to satisfy the requirements of this section may be non-canopy trees.
         o.   Except as otherwise specified by this section, an automatic
irrigation system shall be installed in each required landscaped area.
         p.   Landscaping islands are required in parking areas containing more
than 80 parking spaces.  Each separate landscaping island shall contain a
minimum area of one hundred and fifty (150) square feet; shall have a minimum
width of nine (9) feet; and shall include at least one canopy tree or two non-
canopy trees.  The remaining area shall be landscaped with grass, groundcover
and/or shrubs, with shrubs limited to a maximum height of three (3) feet from
grade.  Landscaped area in parking islands is counted toward the total
landscaped area required for the lot.
      2.   Landscape requirements for new one-family dwellings and new two
family dwellings:
         a.   Each one-family dwelling and each two-family dwelling constructed
after the effective date of this section shall have at least one (1) tree on
the lot in order to receive a certificate of occupancy.  This can be
accomplished either through preservation of a minimum 6-caliper inch tree or
planting a tree with a minimum size of container class #10.
         b.   The exemptions set forth in Section 43-64 of the Longview City
Code do not apply to this section.
         c.   Anything in this section to the contrary notwithstanding, a
development that is a one-family dwelling or a two-family dwelling or an
accessory use to a one-family dwelling or two-family dwelling is not required
to have an automatic sprinkler system.
         d.   Except as otherwise specified in this section, the requirements
of this subsection (2) shall constitute the only requirements of this section
applicable to a lot occupied solely by a one-family dwelling (and any
associated accessory uses) or a two-family dwelling (and any associated
accessory uses), and no requirements of this section other than those set forth
in this subsection (2) shall apply to any such lot.
      All trees required to be preserved under Article VII to Chapter 43 of the
Longview City Code must be maintained until a site plan is approved and a
building permit application has been submitted.
   C.   Landscape Planting and Criteria, Standards, and Specifications
      1.   Plant criteria
         a.   All plant materials planted to satisfy the requirements of this
section shall be of a species that will conform to the selection criteria
below:
            1.   Plant materials shall either be acceptable native plants or
plants that are known to be acclimated tot he East Texas region.  The developer
shall have the burden of proving that a plant is native to or acclimated tot eh
East Texas region.
            2.   Each plant used to satisfy the requirements of this section
shall be of a species adaptable to the specific environment and conditions in
which it will be planted; i.e., soils, water availability, height limitations,
shade and similar concerns.  The developer shall have the burden of proving
that a plant species is adaptable to the specific environment and conditions in
which it will be planted.
            3.   Artificial plants are not acceptable in satisfying any
requirement of this section.
            4.   All required landscaped areas that are not occupied by trees,
shrubs, planting beds, signs or other permitted fixtures shall be planted with
grass, sod or other suitable groundcover.  The City Planner may permit the use
of decorative gravel and like materials, provided that such surfaces do not
constitute more than thirty percent (30%) of the area used to meet the
landscaped area requirement.  Existing trees to be preserved for landscape
credit must be clearly marked as such.
         b.   Trees and shrubs planted in order to satisfy the requirements of
this section shall conform to the minimum size specified below:
            1.   Trees shall be a minimum size of container class #10 upon
planting.
            2.   Shrubs shall be a minimum size of container class #3 upon
planting.
      2.   Planting and Care Standards
         a.   Landscaping shall be installed in accordance with professional
horticultural/nursery standards and procedures to minimize stress to the
plants.  Planting of all or a portion of plant materials may be continued
during winter months, provided that plant materials are not subject to severe
freezing.  In the event that weather conditions are not suitable for planting,
with the approval of the City Planner, and prior to the issuance of a
certificate of occupancy, a bond, cash bond or irrevocable letter of credit
assigned to the City of Longview in an amount equal to the cost of all required
landscaping improvements shall be required.  The bond, cash bond or letter of
credit shall be effective for a period of time to be determined by the City
Planner, but in no event shall the City Planner require such a bond, cash bond
or letter of credit to be effective for longer than two (2) years.  After the
bond, cash bond or letter of credit has been submitted to and approved by the
City Planner, a certificate of occupancy may be issued (provided all other
applicable requirements for a certificate of occupancy have been satisfied). 
If landscaping is not fully installed and protected in compliance with the
applicable landscape plan within 180 days after the issuance of the certificate
of occupancy, the City Planner may use the bond, cash bond or letter of credit
to provide for the installation of any landscaping required for compliance with
the approved landscape plan.
         b.   The owner or the owner's contractor shall furnish, install and
protect all plant materials in accordance with the landscape plan submitted
pursuant to Section 9-112 and approved by the City Planner.
         c.   Plant materials shall be spaced so that the drip line, branches,
and root ball of any mature plant do not cause, or have the potential to cause,
damage to sewers, sidewalks, overhead utilities or other public improvements.
   D.   Landscaped Area Preservation and Maintenance During and After
Construction
      1.   Existing trees preserved in order to fulfill the requirements of
this section shall be barricaded prior to and during grading and construction
to prevent said trees from soil compaction, stacking of oil within prescribed
drip line areas, construction traffic, changes in grade and similar
construction practices that could affect existing trees.  Methods of protection
other than barricades may be employed if approved in advance by the City
Planner.  The barricades or other acceptable method of protection shall provide
an area around the protected tree having a minimum of one foot of radius for
each one (1) inch of caliper of the protected tree.
      2.   All existing undergrowth in a protected area shall remain until
construction is complete and can only be removed at that time by hand clearing.
      3.   The owner, or an agent for the owner, shall be responsible for the
continued maintenance of all landscaping, which shall be maintained in good
condition so as to present a healthy, neat and orderly appearance, and shall be
kept free from refuse, debris and weeds.
      4.   The lot owner shall replace dead plant materials as required by this
section.  Replacement must occur within one hundred eighty (180) days from the
date on which the City Planner notifies the lot owner of the dead plant
materials.  Replacement plant materials should be of reasonably similar
character to the plant materials being replaced.  At a minimum, replacement-
plant materials shall be sufficient to satisfy the requirements of this
section.  Failure to replace dead plant materials as required by this section
shall constitute a violation of this section.
      5.   Nothing in this section shall prohibit or restrict the City or any
public utility company from trimming trees or removing plant materials that are
a hazard to its employees, to its utility facilities or to the public, or that
may threaten or interfere with the provision of continuous services by the City
or the public utility company.
   E.   Phased Development
      Each phase of a phased project shall comply with requirements of this
section.  The portion(s) of a lot left for subsequent phases shall, at a
minimum, equal the minimum lot size required by this ordinance for the zoning
district in which the lot is located.  No building permit shall be issued for a
subsequent phase of the project until all requirements of this section have
been satisfied on the completed phases.
   F.   Floodway/Floodplain
      On sites where a floodway exists, the floodway will be subtracted from
the total lot area when calculating the landscape requirements.  Therefore,
plant materials in the floodway will not be applicable in satisfying the
requirements of this section.  Area located in a floodplain but not a floodway
will not be subtracted from the total lot area when calculating the
requirements of this section.  Therefore, plant materials in the floodplain but
not in the floodway may be preserved to satisfy the requirements of this
section.
   G.   Parkways, ROW, and Easements
      With the exception of sod, grasses and groundcovers, landscaping in
utility easements, parkways, and public rights-of-way shall be prohibited,
except with the prior written consent of the City Planner and all affected
utilities.  Any damage or interference with utility lines or other utility
facilities resulting from landscape placement, landscape installation or from
negligence by the lot owner, or the agent or employees of the owner, in the
installation and/or maintenance of required landscaping is the responsibility
of the lot owner.  If permitted landscaping that is installed in a utility
easement, or required landscaping installed adjacent to an easement or public
right-of-way, is damaged or killed in conjunction with the maintenance of
utilities or right-of-way, it shall be the responsibility of the lot owner to
repair said landscaping and replace any plant materials that are dead or
damaged.  It is the responsibility of the lot owner (surface owner) to maintain
sod, grasses and groundcovers in any rights-of-way and/or easements located on
the lot.
   H.   Compliance Required
      A certificate of occupancy shall be withheld until the applicant for the
certificate of occupancy demonstrates compliance with all applicable
requirements of this section.
9-112   Landscape Plan Required
   A.   Applicability
      1.   This section does not apply to lots located within the Central
Business district (CB).
      2.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a one-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any).
      3.   This section does not apply to any lot occupied solely by a two-
family dwelling and its accessory uses (if any).
      4.   This section does not apply to any lot on which there is no
development.
      5.   This section does not apply to any expansion of an existing
development if the expansion will not do any of the following:
         a.   increase the total square footage of a building and its
associated parking lot by twenty-five percent (25%) or more; or
         b.   increase the number of stories of a building and increase the
total square footage of the building by twenty-five percent (25%) or more.
      6.   The requirements of this section do not apply to that portion of a
parking lot that existed before the effective date of this section.
      7.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to a lawful non-
conforming development.  However, except as expressly provided otherwise in
this section, an abandonment, expansion, destruction or change in use of a
lawful non-conforming development shall cause the lawful non-conforming
development to lose its status as a lawful non-conforming development and said
development shall thereafter be subject to the requirements of this section. 
For purposes of this section, "destruction" of a lawful non-conforming
development means damage by fire, explosion, flood, tornado, or similar
catastrophic event where the cost of repair exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      8.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to the
reconstruction of a lawful non-conforming development due to damage by fire,
explosion, flood, tornado, or similar catastrophic event if the damage to the
lawful non-conforming development does not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the
reasonable value of the lawful non-conforming development as the lawful non-
conforming development existed prior to the damage.
      9.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section shall apply in each instance where a one-family dwelling or a two-
family dwelling exists in a zoning district other than SF or TF and a change in
occupancy results in a more intensive use.
      10.   Anything to the contrary in this section notwithstanding, this
section applies in each instance where a lot is rezoned from either SF or TF to
a zoning classification other than SF or TF and the lot or any portion of the
lot is converted to a use that is not allowed in either SF or TF zoning
districts.
      11.   For any lot greater than two (2) acres in size, the applicant may
request that this section apply to only a portion of said lot.  The applicant
must specify the portion of the lot to which this section will apply.  The
portion specified by the applicant must, at a minimum, include the entire
portion of the lot on which any development is proposed.  In addition, the size
of the excluded lot area must, at  minimum, equal the minimum lot size required
by this ordinance for the zoning district in which the lot is located.  For
purposes of this section, the term "excluded lot area" means the area of the
lot that lies outside the portion specified by the applicant.  The City Planner
shall not approve the applicant's request if the request violates the spirit or
intent of this article or fails to comply with this article.  The City Planner
shall not approve the request if approval of the request would result in
exempting from this section any then-existing development to which this section
already applies.
   B.   Landscape Plan Requirements
      1.   A landscape plan shall be submitted to the City Planner as a part of
the application for a building permit, pre-submission proposal, or certificate
of occupancy if the development must comply with any of the requirements of (a)
Chapter 43 of the Longview City Code or (b) Sections 9-108 through 9-112,
inclusive, of this ordinance.  The landscape plan shall show compliance with
all applicable provisions of Sections 9-108 through 9-112, inclusive, and with
all applicable provisions of Chapter 43 of the Longview City Code.  A site plan
submitted pursuant to Section 7-200 of this ordinance may also serve as a
landscape plan under this section if the site plan meets all the requirements
applicable to a landscape plan under this section.
      2.   The landscape plan shall consist of a minimum of four prints.  The
landscape plan must have a scale of 1:50, or greater, and be depicted on a
standard twenty-four (24) inch by thirty-six (36) inch page.  A landscape plan
which cannot be drawn in its entirety on a twenty-four (24) inch by thirty-six
(36) inch sheet must be drawn with appropriate match lines on two (2) or more
sheets.
      3.   The landscape plan may be provided by any individual, provided that
the landscape plan is legible and clearly denotes compliance with the
requirements of this section.  Plans that do not clearly demonstrate compliance
with this section, or that do not comply with all applicable regulations, will
be returned unapproved.
   C.   Landscape Plan Contents
      A landscape plan must contain the following information:
      1.   scale and north arrow;
      2.   location and dimensions of boundary lines;
      3.   planting schedule, including the location, height and dimensions of
proposed landscaping, buffer yard location and height, materials, or detail of
proposed fencing and berms;
      4.   description of proposed plantings, including names, locations,
quantities, container or caliper sizes, heights, spacing at the time of
installation;
      5.   identification of the names, locations, and caliper of existing
trees to be preserved to satisfy the requirements of Section 9-111 of this
ordinance;
      6.   description of measures to protect existing trees to be preserved to
satisfy the requirements of Section 9-111 of this ordinance;
      7.   irrigation plan;
      8.   any other information that the City Planner may reasonably require
in order to demonstrate that the proposed development will comply with all the
requirements of Sections 9-108 through 9-112, inclusive, and the requirements
of Chapter 43 of the Longview City Code.  Such other information may include,
but is not limited to, elevations, cross-sections and/or renderings
demonstrating such compliance.
   D.   Landscape Plan Amendments
      The City Planner may approve amendments to an approved landscape plan if
the plan, as amended, complies with all applicable requirements of Sections 9-
108 through 9-112, inclusive, of this ordinance.
9-113   Variances
   The Zoning Board of Adjustment of the City of Longview, as constituted in
Article 18 of this ordinance, and in accordance with the applicable procedures
described in Section 18 of this ordinance, shall be authorized in specific
cases, to grant variances from Sections 9-108, 9-109, 9-110, and 9-111 of this
ordinance.  A variance may be granted if an applicant demonstrates that a
variance would not be contrary to the public interest, and, due to special
conditions, a literal enforcement of the ordinance would result in unnecessary
hardship, and so that the spirit of the ordinance is observed and substantial
justice is done.  It shall be incumbent upon the person seeking a variance to
submit evidence attesting that the grant of a variance would not be contrary to
the public interest, and is requested due to special conditions, and that the
literal application of this ordinance would result in unnecessary hardship. 
Self-induced or monetary hardships shall not constitute a justification for the
grant of a variance.
Article 10
Vehicle Parking Regulations
 
10-100   General
   A.   In any district except Central Business (CB), the off-street parking
regulations are listed by use in Section 10-104.
   B.   When a lot is used for a combination of uses, off-street parking
requirements are the sum of the requirements for each use and no off-street
parking space for one use is included in the calculation of off-street parking
requirements for any other use.  However, with regard to classrooms, fellowship
halls, meeting rooms, offices, and any other multi-purpose rooms or buildings
built in conjunction with a church or rectory, the off-street parking
requirements shall not be the sum of the requirements for each use.  Instead,
the off-street parking requirements for a church or rectory and any multi-
purpose rooms or buildings built in conjunction with a church or rectory shall
be as specified in Section 10-104(C)(2) of this ordinance. (Ordinance No. 3212)
   C.   The following floor areas are excluded in computation of required off-
street parking:
      1.   floor area devoted to off-street parking.
      2.   floor area of a private balcony that is not accessible to the public
and does not provide a means of ingress or egress.
      3.   areas such as display windows that are permanently designed to
display a product or advertise for services and are less than ten (10) feet in
width.
      4.   areas between the exterior entrance doors and utilized floor area of
the building commonly referred to as air stops or vestibules.
   D.   In determining required number of parking spaces, fractional spaces are
counted to the nearest whole number, the one-half (½) counted as an additional
space.
   E.   Except for single-family (attached and detached) and two-family uses,
head-in parking adjacent to a public street where the maneuvering of the
vehicle in parking or leaving the parking space is done on a public street, is
excluded in computing off-street parking requirements.
   F.   In all districts except Central Business (CB), required off-street
parking must be available as free parking or contract parking on other than an
hourly or daily feed basis. This requirement does not apply to institutional
uses.
   G.   A parking space must be at least twenty (20) feet from the right-of-way
line adjacent to a street or alley if the space is located in an enclosed
structure and if the space faces upon or can be entered directly from the
street or alley. This provision controls over any building line platted to a
lesser setback and any other provision of the zoning ordinance.
   H.   Except as specifically permitted in this article, all off-street
parking must be provided on the lot occupied by the main use.
   I.   In multiple-family (MF) and non-residential districts, off street
parking may be provided on a separate lot that is:
      1.   dedicated to parking used by an instrument filed with the Building
Official and consolidated with main use under one certificate of occupancy with
main use;
      2.   located in the same zoning district as the main use or in a district
which allows a commercial parking lot or garage; and
      3.   located within three hundred (300) feet (including streets and
alleys) of the property upon which the main use is located. The distance
measured is the shortest distance between the two tracts.
   J.   The Board of Adjustment may not authorize the placement of required
parking in a residential district if the parking is to serve a non-residential
use located in a non-residential district.
   K.   In Single-Family (SF)-1, SF-2, SF-3, SF-4, SF-5, Two-Family (TF)-1, TF-
2, TF-3, Multi-Family (MF)-1, MF-2, MF-3, Office (O) and Neighborhood Services
(NS) Districts, no portion of a street, alley, public right-of-way, lot,
garage, carport or other structure shall be used for the parking or storage of
any truck, truck-tractor, farm tractor or associated trailer as these terms are
defined in Section 541.201 of the Texas Transportation Code, except panel and
pickup trucks not exceeding one and one-half  (1½) tons capacity.
   L.   In calculating off-street parking requirements, gross floor area
dimensions from exterior wall to exterior wall shall always be utilized except
where otherwise specified in Section 10-104.
   M.   In Parking (P), Commercial (C1 and C2), Industrial (I1 and I2), and
Central Business (CB) zoning districts, off street parking may be provided on a
separate lot as authorized under the “Parking Lot” use.
   (Ord. No. 3721, § 2 10-14-10)
10-101  Construction and Maintenance Provisions for Off-Street Parking
   A.   Each off-street parking space must be provided in accordance with the
following dimensional standards.
      1.   A parking space parallel with the access lane must be twenty-two
(22) feet  long and eight (8) feet wide. A one-way access lane must have a
minimum width of ten (10) feet; a two-way access lane must have a minimum of
twenty (20) feet.
      2.   All other parking spaces must be provided in accordance with Table
10-1 except those spaces falling under the provisions of Section 10-102.
   B.   For uses other than single-family or two-family, each off-street
parking space must be clearly identified by use of stripes, buttons, tiles,
curbs, barriers or other methods approved by the Traffic Engineer.
   C.   For use other than a single-family or duplex use, the surface of an
enclosed or unenclosed parking spaces, maneuvering area for parking or a
driveway, which connects to a street or alley, must be on a compacted sub-grade
and consist of:
      1.   concrete paving,
      2.   hot mix asphalt paving which consists of a binder and surface
course; or
      3.   a material, which has equivalent characteristics of Section 3(a) or
3(b) and has the approval of the Building Official.
   D.   The owner of off-street parking for a use other than one or two-family
shall:
      1.   keep the parking surface and access drive for required parking free
of potholes and surface defects;
      2.   maintain any required wheel guards and barriers; and
      3.   maintain non-permanent parking space markings such as paint so that
clear identification of each parking space is apparent.
   E.   All off-street parking spaces for uses other than single-family
detached shall have wheel guards or other barriers approved by the Traffic
Engineer to prevent parking on unimproved surface or right-of-way.  Wheel
guards or other barriers shall be placed to prevent any vehicle from
overhanging right-of-way.
   F.   Any lighting used to illuminate off-street parking areas shall be
directed away from residential property and structures in such a way as not to
interfere with residential use.

10-102  Provisions for Compact Vehicles
   A.   This section may be utilized for any single non-residential use or
combination uses in one structure or which are considered part of the same
development requiring more than fifty (50) parking spaces.
   B.   Up to twenty (20) percent of the required off-street parking spaces may
be designated as “compact vehicle spaces.”  Any fraction of a space shall be
rounded to the nearest whole number in calculation.
   C.   The minimum dimensions of a compact vehicle space shall be seven and
one-half  (7½) feet in width and eighteen feet in length.  Minimum access lane
width shall be ten (10) feet for one-way traffic and twenty (20) feet for two-
way traffic if the access lane is to serve only compact vehicle spaces.  All
other compact parking spaces must be provided in accordance with Table 10-2.
   D.   To qualify for this provision all compact vehicle spaces must be
clearly identified.
